comment.author: 36899742@N00
comment._content:
George I, King of Hellenes, was a Danish prince who was elected king by the Greek people in 1863. He ruled for 50 years but was assassinated during the Balkan Wars on March 18, 1913. He was the grandfather of England's Prince Phillip. He lay in state in Greece for five days, so the services here would have coincided with his funeral in Greece.

I couldn't find a photo of a Greek Orthodox church in New York to match this. But I did find that the Holy Trinity Church on 72nd Street burned down in 1927. Perhaps this is that church.

comment.author: 11572312@N00
comment._content: KING OF GREECE MURDERED AT SALONIKA; SLAYER MAD; POLITICAL RESULTS FEARED; Shot While Walking in Captured City -- Dies in Half an Hour. By Marconi Transatlantic Wireless Telegraph to The New York Times. March 19, 1913, Wednesday Page 1, 631 words SALONIKA, March 18. -- The King of the Hellenes was shot while walking in the principal street of Salonika at about 5:15 o'clock this afternoon. Half an hour later his Majesty was dead. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B0CE3DF1730E233A... --------------------------------- This NYTimes article (April 3, 1913) mentions a service in NYC at the Eastern Orthodox Church on 72nd street: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B0CE6DF103BE6...
